title: Penguin: Determining Outliers
question_text:
A random sample of the weights of $40\text{ Emperor penguins}$ (in pounds) is taken. The table below displays the summary statistics.
Using the IQR method, which conclusion can be drawn about the number of outliers in this data set?
Using the IQR method, which conclusion can be drawn about the number of outliers in this data set?
tables:
VariableNMeanMedianStandard DeviationMinimumQ1Q3Maximum
Weight4056.142.37.221.332.554.288.7

choices.text: There are no more than $1$ outlier.
There are no more than $2$ outliers.

solution:
To determine if there are any outliers we need to first calculate the value for the Interquartile Range (IQR).

$$IQR=Q3-Q1$$

$$IQR=54.2-32.5$$

$$IQR=21.7$$

To determine if we have any high-value outliers the following formula can be used:

$$Outlier > Q3+1.5\times (IQR)$$

$$Outlier > 54.2+1.5(21.7)$$

$$Outlier > 86.75$$

We can see that we have a maximum value of $88.7$ which is greater than $86.75$ indicating $88.7$ is an outlier. Since we do not know all the values, there may be some outliers between $86.75$ and $88.7$. Right now we can say we have at least $1$ outlier.

As a result, Choices 'A' and 'C' can be eliminated.

To determine if we have any low-value outliers the following formula can be used:

$$Outlier < Q1-1.5\times (IQR)$$

$$Outlier < 32.5-1.5(21.7)$$

$$Outlier < -0.05$$

In this case, there are no low outliers. Therefore, we are not guaranteed to have at least $2$ outliers. We may or may not, but since we do not know the individual values, we cannot say for certain if we have at least $2$ or even less than $2$ outliers.

Choices 'D' and 'E' can be eliminated.

Choice 'B' is our answer.
